annotation.TEXT: And there we have it. Cutman's Bad Scizzors Day is...well, it's not just any old ROM hack, that's for sure. It practically encompasses the entire spectrum of bad ideas that most run-of-the-mill MM2 hacks use, if you really think about it (bad palettes, terrible sprite edits, nonsensical level layout changes, too little changes in some areas, a messed up plot, and so much more).

Also, this is the one part of the fortress where Cutman's speed is actually a detriment. You can try to do this spike drop at full speed, but it's way safer just to abuse the pause trick to reset your momentum.

So, how many of you here hate the color pink with a fiery passion? Why am I asking this? Oh, no reason in particular...but incidentally, if your answer happened to be "yes," you might want to skip over the next stage.

And yet...it somehow manages to be more tolerable than a vast majority of those typical MM2 hacks. Why is that? Well, aside from the absurd dialogue, I think it's mostly due to the speed boost. If this hack was adjusted to be played at normal speed, I could see it getting real old real fast. In a way...it's almost kind of a genius decision (then again, Jason Hayes is the "genious of America" according to the title screen).

Like most of the regular levels, the fortress stages haven't changed all that much (save for some palettes and a minor layout adjustment to Wily 6). Given the minimal changes, it's very easy to breeze through the end-game with Cutman's absurd speed. It's actually kind of fun, and it almost (keyword being 'almost') makes up for a potential soft-lock you can experience in Wily 4.
For reference...honestly, I have no idea how you're supposed to get past that top acid drop without taking damage.

Thanks to that one simple change though, this hack is easily propelled into the "so bad it's good" category. It's a legend among bad ROM hacks for its absurd aesthetics, yet it's actually kind of fun to blitz through some of the stages (especially the fortress ones). Outside of the soft-lock issue in Wily 4 and the initial drop in Wily 6, there's really not a whole lot else in the way of layout issues (aside from maybe those birds in Air Man's stage over the long gaps).

We're close to the end, but we still have one last thing to deal with...and it's a dick move, to be honest. At the start of this stage, hold to the right if you want to avoid the massive pit that makes up the first screen where you'd normally be able to walk around.

And here we have the potential soft-lock location. There's actually a pit to the left of that ladder that seemingly leads nowhere. If you fall into it, there's no way to escape or even die (the only options you'd have left are to either reset the game or shut it off and presumably go play something a bit more sane).

Wasting no time at all, let's blitz through the fortress and take down "Mistah Oats." Who, in actuality, is Wilford Brimley. If you don't know who he is...well, go look up some old Quaker Oats (or Liberty Medical) commercials. Alternatively, you could also watch The Thing (the 1982 version, not the unnecessary 2011 remake).
inb4 my credibility gets shattered because I enjoyed an intentionally bad rom hack.
Personally, I'm kinda disappointed that he didn't mess with the big fish (or the Guts Tank) in some way. Then again, they're already kinda goofy looking enemies.

Overall though, I'll take this hack for what it is: A nonsensical romp through a mostly vanilla MM2 (as far as stage layouts go), mixed with high speeds and graphics that probably came from the darkest depths of MS Paint. Oh, and the credits sequence is...you know what? I'll let you all experience it for yourself. Merry Christmas, happy holidays, and happy new year everybody. Enjoy this bizarre little sign off for now.

Just a slight disclaimer: If you're expecting more terrible sprite edits for the bosses, don't get your hopes up. Aside from the Alien, the OAT Dragon is the only other fortress boss to have modified graphics in some way. Come to think of it, given not much else is changed in the fortress, it makes me wonder if Jason Hayes started running out of ideas by this point.
